item.title: Role-Arity and the Knowing Gradient
item.description:
The meaning crisis is not a shortage of knowledge. It is a culture-wide attempt to do arity-3 operations with arity-2 tools.

Prerequisite

This paper extends the role-arity framework developed in “Role-Arity and the Structure of Emergence.” That paper defines role-arity as the minimum number of functionally distinct slots required for an operation to be well-typed, establishes three thresholds (invariance at arity 1, difference at arity 2, evaluation at arity 3), and develops a diagnostic for question well-formedness based on arity mismatch between a question’s structure and its target’s. The present paper applies the same framework to a different domain: the structure of knowing, and what happens when a culture systematically underspecifies it.

item.title: Role-Arity and the Structure of Emergence
item.description:
Some questions fail because they demand more functional structure than the target can supply, or because they demand less and force a false dichotomy.

The Claim

Structural capabilities emerge at specific thresholds of role-arity â€” the minimum number of functionally distinct roles required for an operation to be well-typed. Role-arity here is not argument-arity; it is the number of functionally distinct slots required for an operation to count as an instance of its operation class. Invariance requires one role. Difference requires two. Evaluation requires three. Each threshold is fundamental at its own level: irreducible within that arity, and insufficient to produce what the next arity makes possible.
